abstracts.cdata!:
Project outcome is overall satisfactory,
            and sustainability is likely. The performances of the Bank
            and the Borrower were overall satisfactory. Four out of six
            lessons drawn from this Project concern the imperative of
            striving for coherence, first within the project design
            itself (i.e. between its objectives, instruments, measures
            of performance, legal stipulations), then between the
            project design on paper and the reality of activities and
            relations in the field ("external" coherence), and
            finally the relation of both of these to the project budget.
            These lessons are not new, and some corrective actions in
            terms of operational policies have been taken since this
            Project was approved, notably the use of design aids such as
            the LogFrame. Still, the subject being difficult, presenting
            these lessons is warranted, even if some repetition is
            involved, especially if the examples involve the
            "external" coherence and relations to the budget.
            !) The first lesson has to do with a comparison between the
            efforts (resources) expanded under a project for some
            activity and the importance that activity has in the
            objectives and outcomes scheme. It stands to reason that
            activities which consume large resources should be reflected
            in the project design as explicit entries in the objectives
            and outcomes framework. 2) The second lesson involves a
            situation which is the inverse of the preceding one, i.e.
            that an activity present in the objectives and outcomes
            framework does not have a realistic budgetary dimension. The
            follow-up activities could not have been much more intense,
            given the number of cities and the distances involved. This
            has posed multiple problems with supervision, first because
            the absence of frequent contacts reduces the policy
            interaction with the clients, and also for the monitoring of
            outcomes (the two are linked). The supervision budgets being
            largely given and modest at best, the difficult lesson of
            this experience is that the policy focus of projects should
            be placed where a solid supervision presence is assured. 3)
            The third lesson concerns the links between the policy
            agenda and the institutional power to make the relevant
            changes. The lesson is to place the onus of a condition
            where there is power to make a change.  4) The fourth lesson
            has to do with weak conditionality, which is a notable
            feature of the Loan Agreement for this Project.5) The fifth
            lesson has to do with economic evaluation of investments
            involving fleet replacement and expansion for public
            transport services. Doing post-investment evaluation of
            fleet replacement in the context of Bank lending requires a
            considerable and expensive effort, which should be
            anticipated while projects are prepared and negotiated, and
            recorded formally in loan/project agreements. 6) The sixth
            lesson is drawn from the experience with sub-loan arrears in
            1999, following the collapse of the ruble against the
            dollar. Most of the client cities had no recourse but to
            step out of the Project. The Bank 's standard advice to
            the client governments is not to pass the foreign exchange
            risk to sub-national entities whose revenue sources are
            limited to domestic currency. A compromise was made in this
            project, at the insistence of the finance ministry, and it
            would have been preferable not to do this.
